results.title: Shelter construction in winter (Outdoor recreation)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Outdoor Education and Recreation”.
Whether camping out over night or just needing a place to rest from the wind and snow, comfortable shelters can be contructed easily, even during winter’s icy blasts. This location film shows the methods used to build a comfortable shelter.

results.title: Firemaking and shelters
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Outdoor Education and Recreation”.
An experienced woodsman and a group are stranded in the wilderness. Led by the woodsman, they locate a good campsite, build a shelter of poles and evergreen boughs, construct a fire reflector and build a fire. The woodsman then demonstrates how a fire can be built even without matches, using the Indian bow and drill method.
results.description:

results.title: Drown-proofing
results.creator_credit: Norman Keziere, Joe Hayward and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Outdoor Education and Recreation”.
Designed to help teach swimmers and non-swimmers alike how to survive a water accident, by showing how to stay afloat and travel in water, even if you have never learned to swim. The majority of men and women can remain on the surface in fresh water, and in salt water the human body is even more buoyant.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman Keziere, Joe Hayward and Moreland-Latchford Productions

results.title: Age of metals: can it last?
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
Episode 7 from the interesting series “Out of the fiery furnace” discusses whether societies accept the environmental penalties of increased metal mining? Are there enough metals left on earth for all who want them? What will we do for energy if the rest of the world is to be carried forward into the Age of Metals? New methods of exploration and detection are shown, including earth-imaging satellites.

results.title: From alchemy to the atom
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
Episode six from “Out of the Fiery Furnace.” Scientists of the 20th century discover how to to transform matter not into gold but into energy. European scientists work towards an understanding of atoms and the energy they release.

results.title: Into the machine age
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
The ever expanding American iron and steel industry spawns the railroads that help to reunify a country riven by civil war. In the aftermath of the Chicago fire on 1871, the industry creates the steel-framed skycraper. The discovery of vast reserves of oil, and the advent of mass production, mark the last quarter of the nineteenth century.

results.title: Revolution of necessity
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
The discovery of how to turn coke into fuel launches the Industrial Revolution. The need for better pumps in the mines eventually leads to the steam engine, which together with the railway transforms society. Bessemer’s converter gives the world cheap steel.
